column4: Does anybody know why after an uptime of about 2-3 days my system really starts to chug? Like, it took me 25 seconds to open a terminal to type in uptime.
Celeron 2.0Ghz, 256MB RAM, Toshiba Notebook.
No, I know :p
This is why I'm curious.
But if I start closing things it doesn't speed anything up.
what are the load averages like in top?
load average: 0.20, 0.40, 0.42
i take it there's no big cpu hogs showing upin top?
nope. But I just sorted by memory, and apparently firefox-bin is still running, after I closed it :\
ps auxw |grep firefox,  get the PID numbers,  then kill -9 PIDnumber
my debian etch firefox has started to do that recently :(
yeah, I've killed it already. I didn't need to use signal 9, 15 was fine. It's helped, but still taking longer than it should :\
how much ram, how much swap in use?
everytime I try to do something it just hammers the hdd.
i wouldn't think of running x on 256megs now a days.  i think you need more ram
ugh. But why does it take 3 days to start to chug?
and why does it fix it when I restart?
it's not releasing memory thinking it will need it again soon
Ah, ok. So it's just reserving it and it's adding up over time.
yes, because it's already done some work on it and doesn't want to throw that effort away.  IIRC you can probably tune the kernel somewhere in /proc but that's beyond me
OK, thanks for your help :)
I fixed it. It appears that wesnothd was running. Wasn't using much, but there was obviously a problem. Killed that and everything works fine again.
what is wesnothd?
Battle For Wesnoth game server.
